analytic.title: Semiglobal Nonlinear Output Regulation With Adaptive Internal Model

div.p: We address the problem of output regulation for nonlinear systems driven by a linear, neutrally stable exosystem whose frequencies are not known a priori. We present a classical solution in terms of the parallel connection of a robust stabilizer and an internal model, where the latter is adaptively tuned to the device that reproduces the steady-state control necessary to maintain the output-zeroing condition. We obtain robust regulation (i.e., in presence of parameter uncertainties) with a semiglobal domain of convergence for a significant class of nonlinear minimum-phase system.

It is in fact well known, since a long time in the case of linear systems [1] and since about ten years or so in the case of nonlinear systems [2], that-if the trajectories/disturbances in question are not known but it is known that they belong to a specified class of functions of time (such as in the classical problem of set point control)-asymptotic tracking can be successfully achieved if the feedback mechanism incorporates a device that is able to "generate" all such trajectories/disturbances. A remarkable feature of the internal-model based control schemes for linear systems [3], [4] is that they guarantee asymptotic decay of the tracking error also in the presence of plant parameter uncertainties (so long as the stability of the overall feedback loop is preserved), a property of paramount importance that has been recently extended also to internal-model based schemes for nonlinear systems [5]- [7].

In linear systems, the role of the internal model is that of securing that the corresponding closed-loop system has a transfer function, between the exogenous input (the uncertain trajectory/disturbance to be followed/rejected) and the tracking error, with a set of transmission zeros that includes all the eigenvalues of the autonomous dynamical system which is supposed to generate all such trajectories/disturbances (the exosystem). The simple consequence of this is that all such exogenous inputs are asymptotically blocked in their transit through the system and this remarkable feature remains in effect despite the plant parameters uncertainties.

Internal model-based control schemes efficiently address the problem of tracking/rejecting families of exogenous inputs, all those that can be thought as generated by a fixed autonomous finite-dimensional dynamical system (the initial condition of which identifies the actual, unknown, exogenous input affecting the plant). In this sense, they generalize the classical way in which integral-control based schemes cope with constant but unknown disturbances. However, the main limitation of these schemes is that a precise model of the system that generates all exogenous inputs must be available, to be replicated in the control law. This limitation is not sensed in a problem of set point control, where the uncertain exogenous input is constant and thus obeys a trivial, parameter independent, differential equation but becomes immediately evident in the problem of rejecting e.g., a sinusoidal disturbance of unknown amplitude and phase. An internal model-based controller is able to cope with uncertainties on amplitude and phase of the exogenous sinusoid, but the frequency at which the internal-model oscillates must exactly match the frequency of the exogenous sinusoid: any mismatch in such frequencies results in a nonzero steady-state error.

Motivated by the wish to remove such a limitation, we address in this paper the problem of designing an internal-model based control scheme in which the "natural frequencies" of the internal model are automatically tuned so as to match those of an exosystem which is totally unknown (except for an upper bound on its dimension). In this context, we provide a control scheme that is able to successfully address the problem of asymptotically tracking/rejecting any family of exogenous inputs generated by some (fixed dimensional, but otherwise completely unknown) autonomous dynamical system, for a significant class of nonlinear systems, in the presence of possibly large parameter uncertainties.

div.head: II. PROBLEM FORMULATION
div.p: The systems we consider in this paper are single-input, singleoutput finite-dimensional nonlinear systems, described by equations of the form (1) with state , control input , and output . The system depends on a vector of unknown parameters , whose values are assumed to range over a known compact set . Without loss of generality, contains the origin in its interior. The vector field and the output map are assumed to be smooth, with and for every value of . The system is driven by an exogenous input generated by a neutrally stable linear time-invariant exosystem of the form (2) The exosystem depends on a vector of unknown parameters, assumed to range over a known compact set . We denote with the regulated error, being a smooth function of its arguments.

The control input to (1) is to be provided by an error-feedback controller modeled by equations of the form (3) with state , in which and are smooth, with , . The problem we consider in this paper is the following: given arbitrary fixed compact sets , , find a controller of the form (3) and a compact set , such that 1) the equilibrium of the unforced closed loop system ( 4) is asymptotically stable for every , with domain of attraction containing the set ; 2) the trajectory of the closed-loop system (5) originating from any initial conditions exists for all , is bounded and satisfies for every and every . We stress the fact that, contrary to the classic formulation of the regulator problem, both in the nonlinear [2] and the linear setting [3], [4], the controller has to be designed on the basis of an uncertain exosystem. A trivial necessary condition for the existence of a solution to the above problem is the solvability for every value of . This, in turn, implies the existence of a local, structurally stable solution [7], that is, the existence of a dynamic feedback controller which solves the problem in a neighborhood of , and a neighborhood of , for every fixed . Byrnes et al. [7] have shown that this can be accomplished only if, given a fixed , there exist mappings and , with and , both defined for , satisfying

for all , and such that the autonomous system with output (7) is immersed into a system defined on a neighborhood of the origin, possessing a detectable linear approximation. Equation ( 6) establishes the existence of a controlled-invariant submanifold of the state space on which the error is identically zero, and whose friend (in the terminology of Wonham [8]) is given by the output of the autonomous system (7). The solution of the problem of structurally stable regulation is then obtained as the parallel connection of two separate controllers of the form ( 8) and (9) The first controller, commonly referred to as the internal model, has the role of generating asymptotically the input , while the second one locally exponentially stabilizes the interconnection of the plant and the first controller [2], [9], [7]. The extension of this methodology to our specific problem faces two obstacles: first, and more fundamental, the internal model (8) can not be directly implemented, as it depends on the vector of uncertain parameters . Second, even in the case in which is known exactly, the presence of the internal model amounts to adding a neutrally stable zero dynamics to the plant model, which renders the stabilization via output feedback of the interconnected structure a very difficult task. Usually, in order to simplify the design of an output-feedback stabilizer, one has to make restrictive hypothesis on the class of systems under consideration, such as feedback linearizability [6] or input-to-state stability of the inverse dynamics of the plant [10], [11]. In this paper, motivated by the results in [12], we employ a particular parameterization of the internal model, which we regard as a "canonical" one. This allows the stabilization problem to be solved in an almost straightforward way if the exosystem is exactly known, under the standard assumption that the zero dynamics of the plant are asymptotically and locally exponentially stable. Most importantly, this parameterization can be viewed as a "certainty equivalence" internal model control, which can be extended to an adaptive scheme to solve the problem in presence of uncertainties in the exosystem. The adaptive controller indeed corresponds to a parameterized family of immersion mappings, which is exponentially convergent to the mapping that generates the unique input that renders the output-zeroing manifold invariant. As an added bonus, one can asymptotically estimate any finite number of distinct frequencies of the harmonics generated by the nonlinear system (not just by the linear exosystem), provided that this number is known.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section III, we state the assumptions necessary to the well-posedness of the problem, and we introduce some notation. The canonical parameterization of the internal model is presented in Section IV. Section V deals with the design of a partial-state feedback regulator in the case of perfect knowledge of the parameter . The adaptive internal model is presented in Section VI, where we address also the issues of convergence of the estimates and minimal parameterization of the adaptive controller. Finally, in Section VII we derive the error-feedback adaptive regulator, and we present a case study in Section VIII.

div.head: VI. TUNING THE INTERNAL MODEL
div.p: The controller designed in the previous section is based on the standard assumption that the parameters of the exosystem are exactly known. This corresponds, in the classical setup of the output regulation problem, to consider as exogenous inputs constant and sinusoidal signals of known frequency and unknown amplitude and phase. If the vector is not known, we need to employ a method to asymptotically estimates the frequencies of the exogenous signal as well. We show how an "adaptive" version of the above controller can be effectively implemented. The adaptation algorithm "tunes" a parameterized family of internal models to the one which reproduces the signals generated by the exosystem and the nonlinearities of the plant. We first derive our controller under the assumption that none of the eigenvalues of the exosystem (and, consequently, of the internal model) are known in advance, and then we show how to modify the scheme when some eigenvalues are in a fixed known location on the imaginary axis.

div.head: IX. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we have shown how one of the greatest limitations of output regulation theory so far, namely the requirement of complete knowledge of the frequencies of the exosystem, can be overcome by incorporating an adaptation mechanism in the internal model-based control. Inspired by the result of [12], we have solved the problem of semiglobal robust regulation with unknown frequencies of the exosystem for a large class of nonlinear systems, in the very general framework of the nonlinear regulator theory of [2]. A case study has been presented to show the effectiveness of the method, which may prove to be of great importance in control applications.
